awd_titl_txt: NCWIT Participation in BPCNet (Broading Participation in Computing Network)
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Center for Women and Information Technology (NCWIT) proposes a project to contribute to the design and population of the Broadening Participation in Computing (BPC) Network Resource Portal (BPCNet), an online set of resources to connect computing researchers with resources and opportunities to participate in BPC activities. NCWIT will collaborate with the Computing Research Association (CRA) in the design and implementation of BPCNet, providing program scaffolding, resources and advice, and playing a key role in its management and leadership. In addition, NCWIT will extend the activities of its most successful and scalable programs to include Computer and Information Sciences and Engineering (CISE) researchers. These include Aspirations in Computing, AspireIT, Counselors for Computing, and Extension Services for Undergraduate Programs, as well as other resources that have been evaluated and packaged as easy to use programs. 

NCWIT's large coalition of corporations, startups, academic institutions, government agencies, and non-profit organizations have a proven track record of successful programs that aim to increase the participation of women in computing. The Aspirations in Computing program, for example, supports women and girls throughout their entire academic and career pipeline by providing access to scholarships, internships, and job opportunities. All of NCWIT's programs involve participation of multiple stakeholders, and thus provide an extensive network that will be key in developing the strategy and infrastructure for the BPCNet initiative.

This award is co-funded by NSF INCLUDES, which focuses on catalyzing the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics enterprise to collaboratively work for inclusive change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the participation of the National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT) in providing services and feedback to the Computing Research Association's Center for Evaluating the Research Pipeline (CRA CERP) as they developed and raised awareness of the BPCnet website and related BPCnet workshops. BPC refers to Broadening Participation in Computing, an NSF Computer and Information Sciences and Engineering (CISE) directorate priority. The website is intended to act as a BPC hub for individual computing faculty and administrators as well as teams from computing departments. The website (www.bpcnet.org), still under revision, was developed to contain information, tools, data, and other resources that help support the computing community to realize greater diversity and inclusion among students, faculty, and entire computing departments.

 NCWIT's participation in this project has included being part of a steering committee, providing professional evaluation services, giving input and feedback on the website based on NCWIT's experiences with developing and curating a virtual hub of resources and programs, supplying both intellectual content and relevant activities to the BPCnet website, helping to develop and implement in-person and virtual workshops to train departments on how to write successful BPC departmental plans. NCWIT also helped to advertise the events and resources available through BPCnet, raising the visibility of CRA CERP's work.

 The BPCnet project has one overarching goal: to encourage departments and faculty to do more to recruit and retain students and faculty from historically excluded groups. The resources and structure enabled by this project will support the CISE BPC plan requirement. If faculty through BPC project plans, and departments through BPC departmental plans, can implement the strategies they write about and do them well, then they will make a difference in diversifying their computing departments. As a consequence, the students' learning experiences and the faculty's teaching experiences in these computing departments will be noticeably changed. In addition, computing as a field will become not only more diverse, but also more welcoming and inclusive of individuals from many different racial/ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and dis/abilities.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Wendy M Dubow
